list_definition.definition: to have in one’s hand(s) or between one’s hands

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: He was holding a knife
Hold that dish with both hands
He held the little boy’s hand
He held the mouse by its tail.

list_definition.definition: to have in a part, or between parts, of the body, or between parts of a tool etc

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: He held the pencil in his teeth
She was holding a pile of books in her arms
Hold the stamp with tweezers.

list_definition.definition: to support or keep from moving, running away, falling etc

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: What holds that shelf up?
He held the door closed by leaning against it
Hold your hands above your head
Hold his arms so that he can’t struggle.

list_definition.definition: to remain in position, fixed etc when under strain

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: I’ve tied the two pieces of string together, but I’m not sure the knot will hold
Will the anchor hold in a storm?

list_definition.definition: to keep (a person) in some place or in one’s power

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: The police are holding a man for questioning in connection with the murder
He was held captive.

list_definition.definition: to (be able to) contain

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: This jug holds two pints
You can’t hold water in a handkerchief
This drawer holds all my shirts.

list_definition.definition: to cause to take place

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: The meeting will be held next week
We’ll hold the meeting in the hall.

list_definition.definition: to keep (oneself), or to be, in a particular state or condition

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: We’ll hold ourselves in readiness in case you send for us
She holds herself very erect.

list_definition.definition: to have or be in (a job etc)

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: He held the position of company secretary for five years.

list_definition.definition: to think strongly; to believe; to consider or regard

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: I hold that this was the right decision
He holds me (to be) responsible for everyone’s mistakes
He is held in great respect
He holds certain very odd beliefs.

list_definition.definition: to continue to be valid or apply

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: Our offer will hold until next week
These rules hold under all circumstances.

list_definition.definition: (with to) to force (a person) to do something he has promised to do

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: I intend to hold him to his promises.

list_definition.definition: to defend

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: They held the castle against the enemy.

list_definition.definition: not to be beaten by

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: The general realized that the soldiers could not hold the enemy for long.

list_definition.definition: to keep (a person’s attention)

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: If you can’t hold your pupils’ attention, you can’t be a good teacher.

list_definition.definition: to keep someone in a certain state

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: Don’t hold us in suspense, what was the final decision?

list_definition.definition: to celebrate

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: The festival is held on 24 June.

list_definition.definition: to be the owner of

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: He holds shares in this company.

list_definition.definition: (of good weather) to continue

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: I hope the weather holds until after the school sports.

list_definition.mean_english: giữ máy điện thoại chờ người cần gặp
list_definition.definition: (also hold the line) (of a person who is making a telephone call) to wait

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: Mr Brown is busy at the moment – will you hold or would you like him to call you back?

list_definition.definition: to continue to sing

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: Please hold that note for four whole beats.

list_definition.definition: to keep (something)

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: They’ll hold your luggage at the station until you collect it.

list_definition.definition: (of the future) to be going to produce

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: I wonder what the future holds for me?

list_definition.mean_english: sự cầm nắm; sự giữ chặt
list_definition.definition: the act of holding

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: He caught/got/laid/took hold of the rope and pulled
Keep hold of that rope.

list_definition.definition: power; influence

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: He has a strange hold over that girl.

list_definition.definition: (in wrestling etc) a manner of holding one’s opponent

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: The wrestler invented a new hold.

list_definition.definition: (in ships) the place, below the deck, where cargo is stored.

list_ex_of_english: We say that is right eresolving if the right resolving condition holds, but with the uniqueness condition replaced by existence.
Archives hold numerous complaints from provincial governors about the insufficiency of security forces under their authority and requests for additional mounted recruits.
In this paper we shall show that this conjecture holds for the branching random walk.
Viewed on a per holding basis the net present value of mean economic returns per holding come to $500/ha.
It holds that it is never permitted to pay for an object x, if x could have been obtained for free.
Yet the criss-crossing of isoglosses shows that it also holds for phonetic or morphological features.
Communist parties held a monopoly of power in communist countries.
The multiple roles that people hold within their family, community, work, and society as a whole work to define their sense of self.
